Notes: Iraq invades Kuwait leading to Gulf War and major oil supply disruption. OPEC member invasion of another member.
Economic crisis spreads across Asia reducing oil demand significantly. Currency devaluations and economic contractions.
Terrorist attacks on US creating uncertainty in global markets and oil prices. Initial spike followed by demand concerns.
US-led invasion of Iraq disrupts Middle East oil production. Uncertainty about Iraqi oil exports.
Global financial crisis triggers sharp decline in oil demand. Largest price collapse in modern history.

Description: Arab Spring and Libyan Civil War
Notes: Unrest in Libya disrupts North African oil production. Loss of ~1.6 million bpd of light sweet crude.
OPEC decision not to cut production despite oversupply from US shale. Beginning of 2014-2016 price collapse.
OPEC decides to maintain production levels at 30 million bpd despite falling prices. Market share strategy.
OPEC agrees to cut production by 1.2 million bpd for first time since 2008. Price stabilization effort.

Description: US Withdraws from Iran Nuclear Deal
Notes: Reimposition of sanctions on Iranian oil exports reduces global supply by ~1 million bpd.
Drone attacks on Abqaiq and Khurais facilities temporarily remove 5.7 million bpd (5% of global supply).
Saudi Arabia and Russia fail to agree on production cuts. Saudi increases production and cuts prices.
WHO declares COVID-19 pandemic. Global lockdowns collapse oil demand. Unprecedented demand destruction.
Largest production cut in history at 9.7 million bpd (10% of global supply) to stabilize prices.
Russian invasion of Ukraine triggers Western sanctions on Russian oil. Supply concerns and redirection of flows.
